Again, though, I really couldn't make out any discernable words with it. Bu=
t that is not to lesson your feelings on it.

  ----- Original Message ----=
- 
  From: SnowfireL@... 
  To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Thursd=
ay, May 21, 2009 9:03 AM
  Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] Perception is Probabilist=
ic






  April, could you hear the one with the 3 men talking about a "ra=
t" mouse" 2 " " where is the super?" pregnant mouse" that came in loud and =
clear for me.  They  kept me up all night, made me laugh.

  In a message d=
ated 5/21/2009 10:57:19 A.M. Eastern Daylight Time, april@abercrombieghostr=
esearch.com writes:




    There is a movie called "What the Bleep Do We K=
now" which is along these lines. Very interesting.

      ----- Original Me=
ssage ----- 
      From: phenom_investigator 
      To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups=
.com 
      Sent: Thursday, May 21, 2009 8:52 AM
      Subject: [EVP-ITC] P=
erception is Probabilistic


      Thought these comments might be interest=
ing in light of recent
      threads. Dr. Sam El-Khazen recently published =
an article in the
      Journal of Neuroquantology (study of brain function=
 at the quantum
      mechanical level). In this paper entitled "DNA The Ga=
teway to
      Time", El-Khazen talks about the relationship between the st=
ructure
      of DNA, time, conscious perception and gravity. There is cred=
ible
      evidence that these are intimately correlated. 

      An import=
ant finding for this group has to do with how we may in
      fact detect e=
xternal influences in the physical world. If El-Khazen
      has it right, =
two EM waves must align in order for the preception
      process to even b=
egin. If this does not happen, there is nothing to
      perceive, even tho=
ugh we may be impacted by an external potentially
      influencing EM wave=
. The second wave is generated from borrowed
      energy within our brain =
cells and is modelled upon the structure of
      DNA strands. So yes we ar=
e impacted by billions of EM signals per
      second but we actually detec=
t only a small portion of these that we
      later process in the late-sta=
ge perceptual processes. 

      This would nicely explain why two people w=
ould perceive events
      differently despite the fact that they were lite=
rally side by side
      witnessing the same event. Again this is strictly =
a matter of
      random probability, it seems to have nothing whatsoever t=
o do with
      volition or intention. That is more the focus of the later
=
      perceptual processing which is in turn dependent upon this
      prob=
abilistic process.

      This could also explain why it is that EVP and IT=
C signals are
      perceived differently by different people even when no =
physical
      alteration to the media has occurred and why different thing=
s are
      heard more easily at different times by the same person.






=
